commentBody: As promised, here is a pic of Foxy, the beloved pomerian in her sunflower cone, spreading joy to all. She is 2.5 weeks post OP from bilateral knee surgery for subluxing patellas. Being penned in is giving her cabin fever. The irony of not being allowed to move after getting a procedure to improve your movement. https://imgur.com/a/t9VvE9N

Surfacing from obscure lurking to say nice job, Kit! (I actually kinda sorta know Kit). I didn't figure out what was going on with the three theme entries until I read the column. But I liked seeing MACGYVERED and the (non-architectural) example of LESS IS MORE.
I feel like this one was way too easy for Thursday but I loved the trick once I spotted it.

Maybe I‚Äôve been doing these things for too long now (8 years, I think?) because I landed this one in about a minute longer than a typical Monday, and only that long because I stopped to think about the theme entries. Was it just me or was this an exceedingly straightforward puzzle?

Sam writes:
   "...it‚Äôs hard enough to design a tight grid without the added zigs and zags of a rebus."

Sam,
Now everyone who reads the column before doing the puzzle is going to be trying to squeeze more than one letter into some squares!

(People are so conditioned to thinking a rebus in a crossword only means a squish.)
3D inspired me to Google "MacGrubered," which I deeply regret.

Solved a rather straightforward puzzle with those curious three rows that I finally figured out what the trick was only after the entire puzzle was solved. A bit interesting, but not all that memorable. But, excellent for a debut!
By far my fastest Thursday. Oh wow. And I don't mean that in a good way.

This theme brought to you by Shakespeare.

36A: When sorrows come, they come not single spies, but in battalions.

52A: Tomorrow and tomorrow and tomorrow creeps in this petty pace from day to day.

20A:  Geez! Is there a funnier bit in a play than the rude mechanicals doing Pyramus and Thisbe?

I kept waiting for something I obviously overlooked to come crashing down.

That was refreshingly different Thursday.
Sonia Sotomayor and Clarence Thomas were Judges.  Now they are Justices.
I solved the whole thing but still didn't understand the theme until I came here!

Xwstats calls this Easy right now, but it‚Äôs definitely bordering on Very Easy. https://xwstats.com/puzzles/2026-01-29?sync=1 Although it‚Äôs a solid puzzle, it probably shouldn‚Äôt have been slotted in as a Thursday.
Fun puzzle, Kit!  Congratulations on your NYT debut. Impressed that you met one of your retirement goals.  I‚Äôve been retired almost 20 years and still haven‚Äôt declutterred my garage.

I thought it was a good puzzle overall.  The theme clues made me a little mad when I figured it out but it was amusing enough to let it slide.

The central west section I found a little annoying.  Like, who the hell has ever heard of GlaxoSmithKline that would make you realize it was FOLIE ADEUX and not FOLIE AMOUR?  And then shouldn't the USNA clue in the region be NAVY, not NAV?

The EEO/MIDGES square was also a bit Naticky for me, I still have no idea what EEO means.  And never heard of a FETE and not familiar enough with Northern Ireland trivia to get it easily with crossing clues.  Then WAG/GONG when I was thinking DONG and never heard of the word WAG.

So good puzzle overall but a few annoying Naticky areas.  It feels like a lot of clues are based on Britishisms that are not common knowledge in the US.

NICE puzzle. Got the row of Gs, stared at it, and then figured it out and filled the remaining theme rows. Smooth fill, except for putting cAdS instead of WAGS; cINGIT was impossible to parse, so I changed c to w. It seemed plausible both with WAdS and dONG (spicy for fill but a short ding-dong might be a signal), but then I changed d to g and was fine. 

Bet we'll get "it should have been a rebus" comments though...

I hope I don‚Äôt start a row, but this struck me as one of those puzzles that was more fun for the constructor than the solver.  The repeating patterns were easy enough to spot and provided a lot of free fill in a puzzle that wasn‚Äôt otherwise terribly hard.  I admit I didn‚Äôt get the significance  of the patterns until I came to Wordplay, at which point I shrugged  ‚Äî clever, especially making all the crosses work, but meh.

[Olympic projectile] ARARARARARARARAR.  Like I said meh.
Sports trivia generally escapes me, but the "Five train in Brooklyn" clue seems like an extra long stretch.

Came in well under average, but not quite a personal best. 

I didn‚Äôt get a chance to figure out the why of the trick until I finished and read the column. 

I hope next week we get a rebus.
Trippy! I liked it. Thank you!

Hope I don‚Äôt start a row, but I wasn‚Äôt a huge fan of this one. My mom and I didn‚Äôt understand the themed entries until we read the column.

I would say it had an unpleasant bouquet, but a smooth finish.

Fastest Thursday ever. Loved the theme, but it made the solve easy.  
Can't believe this is the debut of MacGyvered, but maybe the prior one was MacGyverism. 
Love MacGyver.

A new category ‚Äònonsense fill‚Äô appears to join the US slang and other languages. 
English is of course a hard language to use well. 
I offer Woolloomooloo, Inyarrimanha Ilgari Bundara, as possible options, a suburb of Sydney and the Murchison Radio-astronomy Observatory location respectively.
Quick solve without needing to get the theme - clicked after I finished - very cute

I think the gods must be angry with me (as per usual).

The worst thing that can happen  to a solver is to not bring home a puzzle that everyone else declares is so easy.

Sometimes, when I get a puzzle, someone will comment that they were tripped up by a single entry, and it occurs to me that had I thought of the mistaken entry, I might have been tripped up to.

I think I'll ignore these comments again tonight.

With news of Oscar nominations still relatively fresh, I expected the signal to get off the stage in 7D to be a SONG, and WAGS escaped me as a term for jokesters. I relied on the article to finish this one off, but otherwise it was a very quick solve.
Meh to the theme and meh to all the trivia.

Congrats on your debut, Kit!
You are going to get a few justifiable negative comments today, but don‚Äôt take it to heart. This was a fine debut, a nice puzzle, and cute theme, but it‚Äôs just not a Thursday, and barely a Wednesday‚Äîbut that‚Äôs not your fault. The problem is that once you notice the repetitive nature of the theme entries‚Äîwhich is pretty obvious right away once you get a couple of Gs on the downs in the first themer‚Äîyou can imagine that the other long entries are also repetitive even if you don‚Äôt get the theme right away, so half the puzzle is filled in with almost no work at all. And with only three themers and no revealer, there‚Äôs no real Aha moment while solving. The fill was decent but the clueing was also pretty straightforward for a Thursday (which is  not entirely your fault either).
I did enjoy MACGYVERED a lot especially on the same puzzle with WINGIT and IMONIT. I was able to divine the FABFIVE but not the Brooklyn NETS without crosses; I didn‚Äôt remember they had moved to New Jersey but even if I had I would have called ‚Äúfoul‚Äù on the clue, even if they train in Brooklyn the clue is grammatically way off (unless I‚Äôm missing something?) 
No shade on INIGO Montoya or Princess Bride, but just once I‚Äôd like to see a throwback clue to the great London architect INIGO Jones who is worth learning about.
Anyways, Kit, congrats again this was a fine effort and I look forward to seeing more from you!

Sorry...thought this deserved to be a Tuesday puzzle.
Not up to a usual Thursday standard.

A bit too simple for a Thursday. The theme was not readily apparent until almost the last letter dropped, but the crosses were kind, except for the Naticks of MALI (Maui seemed equally likely) and DERRY/ILY (most texters would use u for you). Still finished in half my usually Thursday time, making this more of a Tuesday puzzle.

I strenuously object to the wording of 57D.

An Open is not a big tennis tournament. It's just a holdover term from when the Open Era began. It means the tournament is open to both professionals and amateurs. I.e., the full name of the US Open is the United States Open Tennis Championships.

The vast majority of professional tennis tournaments, at every level, use the word open in their name. If the clue means Major as in the alternate name for a Grand Slam event, there's actually a negative correlation between the use of the word Open at that level and at lower levels. Only two (US and Australia) out of four use the term Open in their name. At lower levels, the percentage is more than 50%.
Thursday PB! My sense is this was easier than most, but I‚Äôll take what I can get

Don‚Äôt let the theme 

thththththththth

you. It‚Äôs not that

highbhighbhighb.

Gee, not exactly the punishment we expect for a Thursday: a clean, well clued, non rebus  puzzle, with a wacko twist. I liked it a lot; made me smile (bum's place in a bar), made me feel smart (folie √† deux), and I could drop in the fills as I listen to the Warriors' game (also very satisfying).

Kit, there are two camps for every Thursday puzzle: those who carp about it being too hard, the other saying it was too easy.  Ignore them.  Most of us will be delighted to see you again soon.  Congratulations on your debut puzzle!

I don't often kvetch when I don't like a puzzle, but I will make an exception here.   The solving was far too easy for a Thursday, and the theme was a lame contrivance. Sorry, but you can't please everyone.

I decided to persevere on my own though, and sure enough, surprisingly quickly I managed to fill most of the grid, making some ultimately correct guesses for the arcana (the like of FAB FIVE - not only was I unfamiliar with the name: I have no idea how many players there are on any other sport team than in soccer).

With crosses it became obvious what the themed entries would be. Not that I understood the theme, mind you. This was the biggest letdown today - I believe it should not be possible to solve a Thursday without getting the gimmick. It's fine on Monday or Tuesday, but today, when rhe gimmick is supposed to be (IMO, anyway) the main feature of the puzzle? I needed the column to get what I had entered, but I still solved in Wednesday time.

In Poland you are allowed to drink in any vehicle - other than on public transport. What is illegal is exceeding the maximum blood alcohol level. As long as you're under the limit, you can be sipping vodka behind the wheel even. Strangely enough, because it's illegal to drink (rather than be under the influence) in public places, the municipal police often fines people for having an open bottle of alcohol with them on the street or in the park - even if they're not actually drinking.

The answer to 2 down ('capisce') is notionally 'I dig', but that's wrong:  the correct answer should be 'you dig?' or 'dig?' (third-person singular, the polite form of 'capisci', 'you dig?'). 'Capisco' is 'I dig'. I think this clue confuses the shortened gangster dialogue version, 'capeesh', with 'capisce'.

11-down in today's crossword: "Mining waste."

Answer is "slag;" however, mining waste products are called tailings. Slag is the waste material produced when smelting or refining ores.

commentBody:
SAM referenced 'The Gong Show' as the basis for GONG as a signal to get off the stage. But of course its roots are much older than that. It goes back to another meaning of 'gong' -- ordure. So, what might be called a sh-- show is also a gong show.
I suspect, though could find no examples, it may go back to vaudeville and talent shows that, in their casual brutality, would sound the gong to interrupt the unfunny or boring.

MACGYVERED !

Such fun.

Thank you.

The theme is fabulous.

First, while it was easy to fill in, it still left a capital-R Riddle to figure out ‚Äì what do those answers mean?  I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôm not the only one who exulted when the answer hit me.

Second, in a 15-wide grid, those theme answers are limited to one-letter, three-letter, and five-letter repetitions. What a terrific touch to have the theme answers, from top to bottom, go in that order.

Bravo, Kit, on that, and high props for those colorful long downs ‚Äì LESS IS MORE and MACGYVERED.

There were other pings of joy that serendipitously showed up.  SLOG and SLAG.  Symmetrical corner alcohol clues.  The rare sighting of a 15-letter palindrome.  STOOL echoing yesterday‚Äôs LOOTS.  

I was also highly inspired, after reading your notes, to learn that you kept on, didn‚Äôt turn away, even after 30 puzzle rejections.  Wow!

Your debut, Kit, pushed many happy buttons, and thank you for that. Regarding your puzzlemaking future, I see by your name a definite UPARUPARUPARUPAR!

>>It shows that simple math can be elegant, like calculating the area of a parallelogram, or that the prime factorization of 15 is 1 x 3 x 5.

>>The oblique reference to the Scottish Play, *Mac . . . Mac . . . MACGYVER!*

>>The parallel references to Roman and Greek mythology--'twould be nice if Diana and Ares were in-laws, but no, they're half-sibs. (a couple afternoons ago, my Partner and I binge watched old episodes of *Xena, Warrior Princess*, in which the character of Ares, as portrayed by Kevin Smith, figures prominently.)

>>The only clumsy bit was the crossing of ORAL and ORATE, but at least we had NASAL, so to make the otorhinolaryngolists happy.

>>If you're ever driving I-90 between Cleveland, OH and Buffalo, NY, may I suggest you get off the freeway and visit the quaint borough of North East, PA, in the Lake Erie wine country. Like Erie, it's in the northwest corner of the state, but at least it's north east of Erie.

>>Before Lewis tries to tell us this theme has never been done before, it, or something very like, has--in a puzzle from Mon., 1Apr.2019 by Joel Fagliano, which I solved last Thursday while my Partner was having total hip replacement surgery. I thought the puzzle was fun, not overly challenging in the actual solving.  But I had to dive deep into the comments to (hopefully, finally) get the wordplay behind the theme.  

Obviously, I get that G is missing ROW to make GROW (clued as "expand").  Likewise for SOR + ROW and TOMOR + ROW...  

But the wordplay is that it's a *row* of G's. I.e., a row of GROWs that are all missing ROW. So it's like there's a ROW in the numerator and a ROW in the denominator and they cancel out (yielding fidelity to the clue's singularity - "expand" and not "expands").

commentBody:
@Francis

I agree with your argument.

Moreover, your critics say that a foreign language answer would require a foreign language marker in the clue. And yet, right above ADORE we have an entirely foreign language clue with an English answer.

(I assume I'll be told that that's because a foreign language answer requires a foreign language marker in clue, but that a foreign language clue doesn't necessitate a foreign language answer.)

@Bill in Yokohama

Yeah, I appreciate your support, but I hate to think of them as my critics.

I hope they're my cyber-friends who happen to have a different take on some crossword things than I do.

For my part, I feel like any appeal to crossword "rules" are in vain.  

For example, suppose some ingenious constructor made a crossword in which the theme was, somehow, all present tense verbs are past, and all past tense, present.

So, suddenly none of the verbs in the clues matched the answer.

Of course the earth would split in two, but that would, IMHO, be a valid way to make the theme overcome every rule of crosswords.

A hyper-intelligent (or maybe just a modestly intelligent species) might come up with a theme that encoded all the clues and all the answers.  Kinda like a G√∂del Theorem of crosswords.

All I'm saying is that the rules of crosswords are like ice--you don't know how thick they are.

(I invite you to examine the last sentence for potential second meanings.)
@Francis doesn't really fit the clue tho, foreign language or not

@Andrzej

Yes, once it was inferable that the entire row would be Gs, it made the whole top portion pop wide open. 

My experience today, though, was Monday-like because I just‚Ä¶ intuitively knew almost all the answers. The reason I solicited a crowdsourced opinion was because frequently‚Äîusually, really‚Äîmy perceived level of difficult on any particular day is the opposite of most of Wordplay. (Because most people don‚Äôt live under a rock.) 

You and I are usually on opposite ends of the gimme spectrum‚Äîwhich is why I think of you as a guy I‚Äôd definitely have a beer (or a snooty European glass of wine) with [smile].

@Adin

No, probably not.

But when that situation arises as a mistake from a previous entry, it's hard to know how hard to consider each individual square in flyspecing.

I believe in crossword quicksand--it's possible, through a sequence of events, for someone to make a reasonable choice which is like stepping in quicksand.  If you step there, you'll have a real battle to correcting it.

Apologies Andrzej - it's a largely North American reference. Here's my explanation:
Phonics is - at least partly - a system of teaching people how to read by 'sounding out' the words on the page. Occasionally controversial in North American education, with it going in and out of favour in different decades.

When I started school, we were given workbooks to practice in for this sounding out of words. Those books were titled along the lines of Phonics for Early Readers, Phonics 1, Phonics 2, etc. Collectively, Phonics workbooks.

What I'm "hearing" is the result of sounding out (in my head) the letters. For example, seeing TOMORTOMORTOMOR on the screen has me thinking "tow-more-tow-more-tow-more"; which led me to "Three 'tow-more's in a row. Oh! It's a row of 'tow-more's, so a tow-more-row = tomorrow". Which fits the clue.

Similarly, I decoded 37A as a row of sore-sore-sore-...= 'sore-row' = sorrow.

But the process doesn't work for 20A, because when I look at the answer I'm thinking jee-jee-jee-... or guh-guh-guh-...
Extending the "sound it out" pattern from 37A and 52A leads to the nonsense sounding 'row of jees = jeerow', or 'row of guhs = guhrow'. Neither are even English words, never mind being an answer to the clue!

BTW, I also have a hard time with your name. I think of you as 'And-rez-edge', but I doubt very much that that's how your wife says it.

@SBK To the extent that the gong predates "The Gong Show," it still probably postdates Vaudeville, I think. That show borrowed it as a convention from Major Bowes, whose "Original Amateur Hour" debuted on WHN in New York City around April, 1934.

In an interview in 1935, Bowes said that he created it because he had an hour to fill, and used the gong because the stereotypical hook was, of course, a visual gag that didn't work on radio. I, also, can't find examples of gongs being used for that purpose on stage so, if it happened, it was at least rare.

I assume the primary reason Bowes went with it was that he found the dramatic sound funny in the context of a talent show, although as a verb "gong" meaning "to stop" from the use of bells by the traffic police to signal drivers to halt also emerged in the 1930s.

(And of course for a good half-century before that it was familiar in ending sports bouts)

My first thought was the HOOK, but it wasn't really a fit for the clue...  then, there was the "cut throat" motion--no space for that one...

That is a great analysis that makes sense.  Thank you.
